titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Guide to the Communication Department, records, 1917-2002 RG0090
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 15:00:32 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: School of Media and Public Affairs records
did.abstract: Materials in this collection include departmental files and blueprints for Building YY (814 20th Street, NW). The departmental files include brochures, memorandums, newsletters, flyers, invitations, announcements, photographs, programs, press releases, and posters. They range in date from 1917 to 2002. The materials concern radio programs, television programs, courses, College of General Studies, the Department of Speech and Drama, "GW Underground", WRGW history, drama productions, biographic information, forensics workshops for teachers, speech pathology, audiology, graduate studies, plans for a GW - WETA Communications Center, GW Television Station, courses airing on television, seminars, teleconferences, videoconferences, GW television station services, and High School Discussion Conferences.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Communication Department Records, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The majority of the records were transferred to the University Archives by the Chair of the Department of Communication.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Department of Communication at The George Washington University began in 1987, and offered an undergraduate degree in radio and television communications. Before that it was part of the Department of Communication and Theatre, which offered undergraduate degrees in speech communication, theater, and radio-television. Before 1983, it was known as the Department of Speech and Drama.

Now a part of the School of Media and Public Affairs (SMPA), the curriculum focuses on the media and the many important relationships among media, culture, and the various institution of public life, government, education, corporations, and associations.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials in this collection include departmental files and blueprints for Building YY (814 20th Street, NW). They range in date from 1917-2002. The blueprints were transferred to the University Archives by the Chair of the Department of Communication, while the departmental files were formerly vertical files in the Special Collections Research Center.
Formerly RG9.9

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized in four series: Departmental files, Blueprints, Associate Dean C. Sterling Records on Development of Communication at George Washington University, and reel to reels.

did.unittitle: Departmental files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains brochures, memorandums, newsletters, flyers, invitations, announcements, photographs, programs, press releases, and posters. They range in date from 1917 to 2002. The materials concern radio programs, television programs, WTOP, WCFM, WMAL, WRC, WCFM, courses, College of General Studies, the Department of Speech and Drama, "GW Underground", WRGW history, drama productions, biographic information, forensics workshops for teachers, speech pathology, audiology, graduate studies, plans for a GW - WETA Communications Center, GW Television Station, courses airing on television, seminars, teleconferences, videoconferences, GW television station services, and High School Discussion Conferences.
Formerly vertical files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials from Associate Dean Christopher Sterling pertaining to the creation of the School of Media and Public Affairs, dating from 1980-1996.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The reel to reels will need to be digitized before they can be reviewed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The reel to reels in this collection are a majority recordings of "Lectures in Miniature." Lectures in Miniature was a joint program between GW and WMAL Radio and produced by Lillian Brown, director of the then-department of Radio and Television. The lectures were five minute programs with one member of the GW Faculty in their area of expertise.

did.unittitle: Lectures and presentations recordings
GWU hospital groundbreaking dedication ceremony

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The groundbreaking dedication ceremony for the hospital. Speakers: Dr. John Parks, Mr. Ellison, Mrs. Myer, Hon. John McCormack, Speaker of the US House of Representatives.

did.unittitle: GWU - A changing campus
Clark, Joseph S. - "Congress: A Sapless Branch"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Address by Senator Joseph S. Clark (Democrat, Pennsylvania) - GW Public Affairs series, Lisner Auditorium at 8pm on March 10, 1965. A question and answer session answering such questions as should there be four year terms for Congressmen and other questions about the two party system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discussion of Russian Poetry and literature. Also, radio time taped with Dick Van Dyke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses the nature of mental health, its origins and problems.

did.unittitle: "Lectures in Miniature" recordings

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Lectures in Miniature series was a joint program between News and Public Affairs Department of WMAL Radio and GW. Its purpose was to "bring to the radio listener educational information in a consise, palpable form." The series featured a weekly lecture from a University professor with a three to five minute broadcast on a subject of their choosing. The five daily lectures could be interrelated or independent.

scopecontent.p: Discusses geography's interdisciplinary role in education.
